none: Letter 'To the Faculty' from Louis L. McInnis, March 4, 1890
Letter 'To the Faculty' from Louis L. McInnis, March 4, 1890
Box 2 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 2 Folder 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers
Texas State Agricultural and Mechanical College--Administration
Texas State Agricultural and Mechanical College. Board of Directors
Texas State Agricultural and Mechanical College. Faculty

en: A formal letter from Louis L. McInnis, Chairman of the Faculty at Texas State Agricultural and Mechanical College, addressed to the college faculty on March 4, 1890. McInnis requests faculty assistance in fulfilling duties assigned to him by the Board of Directors, specifically referencing institutional regulations and emphasizing his commitment to promoting departmental efficiency and usefulness. The letter establishes the chair's authority and solicits faculty cooperation in institutional governance.

body.value:
[Header]

CHAIRMAN'S OFFICE
STATE AGRICULTURAL AND MECHANICAL COLLEGE OF TEXAS.
(TECHNICAL BRANCH OF THE UNIVERSITY.)

LOUIS L. McINNIS, A. M., PROF. OF MATHEMATICS,
CHAIRMAN OF THE FACULTY.

College Station, Texas, Mar 4 - 90

To the Faculty:-
Gentlemen : I respectfully call your attention
to Section 1 art 2 Chapter I and art 4 of the
same Chapter - and request that each & every
member of the Faculty will assist me in
discharge of the duties imposed upon me
by the Honorable Board of Directors -
I shall do all in my power to promote
the efficiency & usefulness of every de-
partment of the College.

[Signature]

Very Respectfully -
Louis L. McInnis
Chairman.

**Document Transcription and Analysis** Alright, let's get down to it. I've been tasked with transcribing this document, and the details are starting to come into focus. I see a formal letterhead: "CHAIRMAN'S OFFICE," then "STATE AGRICULTURAL AND MECHANICAL COLLEGE OF TEXAS." with a subtitle "(TECHNICAL BRANCH OF THE UNIVERSITY.)" and then the name "LOUIS L. McINNIS, A. M., PROF. OF MATHEMATICS," with the title "CHAIRMAN OF THE FACULTY." It's all printed, clear enough. Then, the handwritten part kicks in. It begins with "College Station, Texas, Mar 4 - 90." The date feels a little old-fashioned, but there it is. The salutation is addressed "To the Faculty:-", then "Gentlemen :". The body of the letter is where things get interesting. The writer, presumably McInnis, is calling attention to sections of a document – specifically, Section 1 art 2 Chapter I and art 4 of the same Chapter – and requesting the Faculty's assistance in fulfilling his duties as imposed by the Board of Directors. It seems like a directive, but expressed politely. He’s promising to promote the "efficiency & usefulness of every department of the College". Looking closely at the handwriting, there are a few quirks. The symbol for "and" is a shorthand. The phrase "discharge of the duties" is written with a gap. The signature, "Louis L. McInnis", is distinct. The closing is "Very Respectfully -", followed by his signature and title "Chairman.". Now, let's get this transcribed correctly. Here's what I've got: [Header]

CHAIRMAN'S OFFICE
STATE AGRICULTURAL AND MECHANICAL COLLEGE OF TEXAS.
(TECHNICAL BRANCH OF THE UNIVERSITY.)

LOUIS L. McINNIS, A. M., PROF. OF MATHEMATICS,
CHAIRMAN OF THE FACULTY.

[Body]

College Station, Texas, Mar 4 - 90
To the Faculty:-
Gentlemen : I respectfully call your attention
to Section 1 art 2 Chapter I and art 4 of the
same Chapter - and request that each & every
member of the Faculty will assist me in
discharge of the duties imposed upon me
by the Honorable Board of Directors -
I shall do all in my power to promote
the efficiency & usefulness of every de-
partment of the College.

[Signature]

Very Respectfully -
Louis L. McInnis
Chairman.
